title: 109_s2636
content: The "Oil Company Accountability Act" may be cited as the short title. It introduces an Energy Tax Rebate under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The section outlines a general rule where individuals are treated as having made a $500 payment towards the tax for the year 2006. The Secretary is required to remit this payment to taxpayers within 30 days of enactment. Certain individuals, estates, trusts, and nonresident aliens are not eligible for this payment. Additionally, there are conforming and clerical amendments made to the Internal Revenue Code. The Oil Company Accountability Act of 2006 excludes certain individuals, estates, trusts, and nonresident aliens from receiving a $500 tax payment. Amendments are made to the Internal Revenue Code as a result of this act. The Oil Company Accountability Act of 2006 excludes certain individuals from receiving a $500 tax payment. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code include a revaluation of LIFO inventories of large integrated oil companies. The effective date for the amendments is the date of the enactment of this Act. The Oil Company Accountability Act of 2006 amends the Internal Revenue Code for integrated oil companies, requiring an increase in the value of historic LIFO inventories and a decrease in cost of goods sold. If the increases exceed the cost of goods sold, gross income is adjusted accordingly. The layer adjustment amount is calculated based on the number of barrels of crude oil. The Oil Company Accountability Act of 2006 amends the Internal Revenue Code for integrated oil companies, requiring an increase in the value of historic LIFO inventories. The layer adjustment amount is calculated based on the number of barrels of crude oil or barrel-of-oil equivalents. Adjustments required by this section are not considered a change in accounting method. No addition to tax shall be made for underpayments of estimated tax. The term "applicable integrated oil company" is defined as an integrated oil company with specific production and revenue criteria. All persons treated as a single employer under certain sections of the Internal Revenue Code are considered as such for this purpose. The term "applicable integrated oil company" refers to an integrated oil company with production of at least 500,000 barrels of crude oil and gross receipts exceeding $1,000,000,000 in the last taxable year ending in 2005. All persons treated as a single employer under specific sections of the Internal Revenue Code are considered as one entity for this purpose. MODIFICATIONS OF FOREIGN TAX CREDIT RULES FOR LARGE INTEGRATED OIL COMPANIES. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include special rules for large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. Any amount paid to a foreign country or possession of the United States by such companies will not be considered a tax under certain conditions. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 includes special rules for large integrated oil companies that are dual capacity taxpayers. A dual capacity taxpayer is defined as a person subject to a levy of a foreign country or possession of the United States. Any amount paid by such taxpayers to a foreign country or possession will not be considered a tax under certain conditions. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 has special rules for dual capacity taxpayers, who are individuals subject to a levy of a foreign country or possession of the United States. The term 'generally applicable income tax' refers to income taxes imposed by a foreign country or possession on income derived from a trade or business within that country or possession. The term 'income tax' refers to taxes imposed by a foreign country on income from a trade or business within that country. Exceptions include taxes that do not apply to dual capacity taxpayers or citizens/residents of the foreign country. A 'large integrated oil company' is defined as one with gross receipts over $1,000,000,000 and an average daily worldwide production. The term 'large integrated oil company' is defined as an integrated oil company with gross receipts exceeding $1,000,000,000 and a daily worldwide production of at least 500,000 barrels of crude oil. The amendments made by this section apply to taxes paid or accrued in taxable years beginning after the enactment date, except where contrary to any U.S. treaty obligations.
